title: 115_hr2919
content: The Act titled "Preserving Teacher Loan Forgiveness for Military Spouses Act of 2017" allows teachers whose employment is interrupted due to military orders requiring relocation to continue participating in student loan forgiveness programs. The Act allows military spouses who work as full-time teachers for 5 non-consecutive years to be eligible for loan forgiveness, even if they were qualified military spouses during years when they were not teaching. A "qualified military spouse" is defined as an individual who served as a teacher in a school meeting specific requirements, is the spouse of a member of the Armed Forces relocated due to military orders, and did not teach in a qualifying school during the previous year. The Secretary must report to Congress every 2 years on the implementation of the provision allowing qualified military spouses to resume teaching in a qualifying school after accompanying their spouse on military orders. The Secretary must report to Congress every 2 years on the number of individuals eligible for loan forgiveness under subsection (b) due to certain military spouses being employed as full-time teachers for 5 complete years. The term 'qualified military spouse' is defined as an individual who served as a teacher in a school meeting specific requirements in the previous year and is the spouse of a member of the Armed Forces relocated due to military orders. The term 'qualified military spouse' refers to an individual who served as a teacher in a specific school in the previous year and is the spouse of a member of the Armed Forces relocated due to military orders. The individual must not have served as a teacher during the year due to accompanying their spouse on a change of duty station, but must resume teaching in a qualified school the following year. Additionally, a report to Congress is required within 90 days. The Secretary must report to Congress every 2 years on the number of individuals eligible for loan cancellation under subsection (b) as a result of the new provisions. The amendments apply to individuals who start full-time teaching after the enactment of the Act.
